name: Product Backlog Essentials
description: Capture what the users of a system want it to do as a priority-ranked list of independently buildable items.

activitySpaces.name: Understand the Requirements
activitySpaces.description: Establish a shared understanding of what the system to be produced must do. Understand the requirements to: Scope the system, Understand how the system will generate value, Agree on what the system will do, Identify specific ways of using and testing the system, Drive the development of the system.

activities.name: Refine Product Backlog
activities.description: Get and keep the Product Backlog visible, up-to-date and in good working order, with high priority items well understood.

activities.name: Agree Definition of Done
activities.description: Agree the quality criteria that will be used to determine whether any change to the product is fully and correctly implemented.

activities.name: Prepare a Product Backlog Item
activities.description: Ensure that the Product Backlog Item is ready for development and that it is clear how it will be tested.

alphas.name: Stakeholders
alphas.description: The people, groups, or organizations who affect or are affected by a software system. The stakeholders provide the opportunity, and are the source of the requirements for the software system. They are involved throughout the software engineering endeavor to support the team and ensure that an acceptable software system is produced.

states.name: Recognized
states.description: Stakeholders have been identified.

states.name: Represented
states.description: The mechanisms for involving the stakeholders are agreed and the stakeholder representatives have been appointed.

states.name: Involved
states.description: The stakeholder representatives are actively involved in the work and fulfilling their responsibilities.

states.name: In Agreement
states.description: The stakeholder representatives are in agreement.

states.name: Satisfied for Deployment
states.description: The minimal expectations of the stakeholder representatives have been achieved.

states.name: Satisfied in Use
states.description: The system has met or exceeds the minimal stakeholder expectations.

alphas.name: Opportunity
alphas.description: The set of circumstances that makes it appropriate to develop or change a software system. The opportunity articulates the reason for the creation of the new, or changed, software system. It represents the team’s shared understanding of the stakeholders’ needs, and helps shape the requirements for the new software system by providing justification for its development.

states.name: Identified
states.description: A commercial, social or business opportunity has been identified that could be addressed by a software-based solution.
checklists: At least one investing stakeholder interested

states.name: Solution Needed
states.description: The need for a software-based solution has been confirmed.

states.name: Value Established
states.description: The value of a successful solution has been established.

states.name: Viable
states.description: It is agreed that a solution can be produced quickly and cheaply enough to successfully address the opportunity.

states.name: Addressed
states.description: A solution has been produced that demonstrably addresses the opportunity.

states.name: Benefit Accrued
states.description: The operational use or sale of the solution is creating tangible benefits.

alphas.name: Requirements
alphas.description: What the software system must do to address the opportunity and satisfy the stakeholders.

workProducts.name: Product Backlog
workProducts.description: An ordered list of things to build into the product to enhance its value.

workProducts.name: Definition of Done
workProducts.description: The quality criteria that will be used to determine whether the product is of acceptable / releasable quality.

workProducts.name: Test Case
workProducts.description: Defines test inputs and expected results to help evaluate whether a specific aspect of the system works correctly.

states.name: Conceived
states.description: The need for a new system has been agreed.
checklists: Stakeholders agree system is to be produced

states.name: Bounded
states.description: The purpose and theme of the new system are clear.

states.name: Coherent
states.description: The requirements provide a coherent description of the essential characteristics of the new system.
checklists: Team knows & agrees on what to deliver

states.name: Acceptable
states.description: The requirements describe a system that is acceptable to the stakeholders.

states.name: Addressed
states.description: Enough of the requirements have been addressed to satisfy the need for a new system in a way that is acceptable to the stakeholders.

states.name: Fulfilled
states.description: The requirements that have been addressed fully satisfy the need for a new system.

alphas.name: Product Backlog Item
alphas.description: Something to build into the product to enhance its value.

states.name: Identified
states.description: A way to enhance the value of a product has been found.
checklists: A way to enhance the value of a product has been found
The item has an agreed name that is unique and meaningful
There is a shared high-level understanding of what the item is and why it is needed

states.name: Ready for Development
states.description: The item is sufficiently well understood that the team responsible for adding it to the product can plan and start the work to get this done.
checklists: The item is well-enough understood by the stakeholders and the team for it to be prioritized for development
The value is understood enough to proceed
The size of the item is understood enough to proceed
The relative priority of the item is agreed

states.name: Done
states.description: The item has been implemented in the product and has been demonstrated to be of adequate quality.
checklists: The item has been included in the product
The stakeholders are happy that the value associated with the item has been realized
The item has been verified as meeting all relevant quality criteria
The item has been validated as being usable and fit-for-purpose

alphas.name: Software System
alphas.description: A system made up of software, hardware, and data that provides its primary value by the execution of the software.

states.name: Architecture Selected
states.description: An architecture has been selected that addresses the key technical risks and any applicable organizational constraints.

states.name: Demonstrable
states.description: An executable version of the system is available that demonstrates the architecture is fit for purpose and supports functional and non-functional testing.

states.name: Usable
states.description: The system is usable and demonstrates all of the quality characteristics of an operational system.

states.name: Ready
states.description: The system (as a whole) has been accepted for deployment in a live environment.

states.name: Operational
states.description: The system is in use in an operational environment.

states.name: Retired
states.description: The system is no longer supported.

alphas.name: Work
alphas.description: Activity involving mental or physical effort done in order to achieve a result. In the context of software engineering, work is everything that the team does to meet the goals of producing a software system matching the requirements and addressing the opportunity presented by the stakeholders. The work is guided by the practices that make up the team’s way-of-working.

states.name: Initiated
states.description: The work has been requested.

states.name: Prepared
states.description: All pre-conditions for starting the work have been met.
checklists: At least one team member ready

states.name: Started
states.description: The work is proceeding.

states.name: Under Control
states.description: The work is going well, risks are under control, and productivity levels are sufficient to achieve a satisfactory result.

states.name: Concluded
states.description: The work to produce the results has been concluded.

states.name: Closed
states.description: All remaining housekeeping tasks have been completed and the work has been officially closed.

alphas.name: Way of Working
alphas.description: The tailored set of practices and tools used by a team to guide and support their work. The team evolves their way of working alongside their understanding of their mission and their working environment. As their work proceeds they continually reflect on their way of working and adapt it to their current context, if necessary.

states.name: Principles Established
states.description: The principles, and constraints, that shape the way-of-working are established.

states.name: Foundation Established
states.description: The key practices, and tools, that form the foundation of the way of working are selected and ready for use.
checklists: Practices needed to start work agreed
Gaps between available and needed way of working understood

states.name: In Use
states.description: Some members of the team are using, and adapting, the way-of-working.

states.name: In Place
states.description: All team members are using the way of working to accomplish their work.
checklists: Inspected and adapted by whole team

states.name: Working Well
states.description: The team’s way of working is working well for the team.

states.name: Retired
states.description: The way of working is no longer in use by the team.

competencies.name: Stakeholder Representation
competencies.description: The ability to gather, communicate and balance the needs of other stakeholders, and accurately represent their views. The stakeholder representation competency is the empathic ability to stand in for and accurately reflect the opinions, rights and obligations of other stakeholders.

levels.name: Assists
levels.description: Demonstrates a basic understanding of the concepts and can follow instructions.

levels.name: Applies
levels.description: Able to apply the concepts in simple contexts by routinely applying the experience gained so far.

levels.name: Masters
levels.description: Able to apply the concepts in most contexts and has the experience to work without supervision.

levels.name: Adapts
levels.description: Able to apply judgment on when and how to apply the concepts to more complex contexts. Can enable others to apply the concepts.

levels.name: Innovates
levels.description: A recognized expert, able to extend the concepts to new contexts and inspire others.

competencies.name: Analysis
competencies.description: The ability to understand opportunities and their related stakeholder needs, and transform them into an agreed and consistent set of requirements. The analysis competency is the deductive ability to understand the situation, context, concepts and problems, identify appropriate high-level solutions, and evaluate and draw conclusions by applying logical thinking.

The development competency is the mental ability to conceive and produce a software system, or one of its elements, for a specific function or end. It enables a team to produce software systems that meet the requirements.

patterns.name: Estimating
patterns.description: Estimating patterns provide guidance on how to maintain work progress measures and forecasting capability. Apply estimating patterns to ensure: Estimates come from the people that will do the work, The disruption to productive work is minimized, Estimates are as accurate as they need to be to support reasonable predictability of progress and accuracy of forecasting.

patterns.name: Relative Estimating
patterns.description: Effort to get Product Backlog Items done is estimated not in absolute units of time, but relative to each other. This allows progress to be predicted based on performance. The unit is often called a “Point”, e.g. a “Story Point” when sizing User Stories. Teams track the Points they earn per time period by getting Items done. This is used to forecast progress, with confidence levels based on the number of data points and stability of conditions.

patterns.name: Product Value
patterns.description: Product Value patterns provide guidance on how to define and prioritize the value to build into the solution. Apply product value patterns to ensure that: Value return on investment is maximized over time, High value does not wait unnecessarily for low value, Effective communication and collaboration is maximized, Process overheads and delays are minimized.

patterns.name: INVEST
patterns.description: An acronym of the quality criteria for a Product Backlog Item to be ready for development: Independent – can be independently built / tested, Negotiable – e.g. in its detail or even into or out of scope, Valuable, Estimable – can be sized, Small – enough e.g. to be implemented rapidly, e.g. in a week or less, Testable.

patterns.name: Splitting Product Backlog Items
patterns.description: Small things get done faster. In agile development there is a continuous and relentless drive to reduce the size of backlog items by splitting bigger items into smaller ones. The key is to ensure that each item delivers value: Splits should support meaningful user interactions, no matter how small or “specialized” (think “thin end-to-end journey / slice”) not technical architecture “dice” (e.g. front-end without back-end), Remember: each and every Test Case is a potential backlog item.
